child abuse... yes, if this child is not wanted... it may cause an increased chanse of being abused.

Should he have been denied his life because of some emotional trama he might bave later in life? I don't think so.

that gets overly-violent! but that's the point, isn't it!

 The flaws you mentioned were child abuse, neglect and over-population. In the case of adoption, the first two are nullified - a family willing to go through the adoption process is also going to be willing and able to care compassionately for their child.
 
 Which leaves over-population. In exactly which way are we over-populating? What are the presentable results of over-population. What are the impacts? If our planet were truly over-populated, would we not be persuing under-sea colonies, floating cities, inter-planetary colonization?

I have not done much research on the direct consequences of over-population. If you could provide a link or a book title on the subject, I would be more than happy to look into it.

 One of my co-workers was adopted. He has a nice house, a great wife and 3 fantastic kids. Maybe no-one told him that you have to be a rapist if you're adopted...?

If it is a child, then no matter what, the child must survive, becuase it has every right to. If the fetus isn't a child, then we can do whatever the hell we wnat with it. But it's a child, since humans only produce children, and not being of other speices, in accordance to the Principle of Biogenesis. Therefore, abortion is wrong in all cases.
 
 

 ...no
 We'd just have a lot of people in poverty or people starving, which we do have.

You can't kill 1/3 of the generation to stop the world from "overpopulating". At anyrate, the world isn't over populated. The entire world can fit in the Island of Bali with each person getting 40 square feet of space. Our resources are currently being wasted, because we have so many. The world can never run out of water; we will always have water, no matter what.
 
 Then why are there starving peoples?
 
 Mainly because of corrupt governments.

Then why don't I haul abortionists off to jail as well? They're killing people!
 
 
 You can try, but it won't be legal.
 
 
I don't know who's been feeding you with the idea that the world is over populated, let alone that abortion will solve the problem.
 
 
 The world is clearly overpopulated as can be seen in Africa and Asia. I never proposed abortion as a solution to the problem. The areas where abortion is used most -the western world- is where it would be needed the least.
 
 
At anyrate, the world isn't over populated. The entire world can fit in the Island of Bali with each person getting 40 square feet of space.

 The world is clearly overpopulated as can be seen in Africa and Asia. I never proposed abortion as a solution to the problem. The areas where abortion is used most -the western world- is where it would be needed the least.

 Being pro-life 'except for rape' doesn't make any sense. It's the same organism regardless of the father.
 
 

 I did not say I was pro life except for rape. If you'll look again, I said that most pro-life people would encourage a bill that makes abortion illegal except in the case of rape. Only because right now abortion is legal at any time!
 
Originally posted by Crim 
 
 You just need to realize that overpopulation isn't necessarily about SPACE. It's about not having sufficient resources (food, water, medicine, even space) to sustain a population. 

 I realize this. But I haven't heard of breaking research in areas like growing crops in deserts, or re-purifying urine. I would think that if the world is truly as over-populated as you make it out to be, we would be desperate for technologies like these.
 
 Also, what is your stance on capital punishment?

The world technically is not overpopulated, there is plenty of food and water for everyone (perhaps not oil, etc), but we're fine on the essentials. The problem is that while people in Africa are dying of thirst we are watering our lawns and washing our cars, while they starve we dump millions of tons of food into the garbage. Yes our fossil fuels and mineral deposits will be exhausted, but like electricity our food will not. Thanks to the Cro-Magnon shift from a hunter-gatherer society to one of food production, food is only limited by the amount of arable land in the world, of which only 45% is actually cultivated, leaving more than half of food resources untapped and unused. 
 Yes, the nature of the idea is idealistic and somewhat naïve, but entirely possible. The unification, cooperation, and sacrifice of every nation towards a common goal is only hindered by our mislead acceptance that we can do nothing on a worldwide level. We as a people have slipped into a state of halcyon, defined by self-induced indifference, ignorance, and apathy. The reality is that if Sudan were an American state the minor sacrifices necessary to save it would be non-existent, the mere title of American is somehow enough. It is incentive enough that the richest 5 percent of the world (which is us) have 314 times the income of the poorest 5%. The potential land and crops are there, the money is there, but the ambition is not. Our only ambitions take the form of greed.
 
 God forbid we have to give up our Explorers for Civics.

I did not say I was pro life except for rape.
 
 
 I understand. The comment wasn't directed at you. It was just general.
 
 
I realize this. But I haven't heard of breaking research in areas like growing crops in deserts, or re-purifying urine. I would think that if the world is truly as over-populated as you make it out to be, we would be desperate for technologies like these.

 I stand up for the child who has no choice

Has anyone actually looked at the procedure for partial birth abortion.
 
 The baby (and yes it is a full term or near full term baby) is actually forced into a breach delivery (already more difficult than a normal birth) and the entire body is extracted except for the head. Then a large guage needle is thrust into the back of the skull and the brain stem is suctioned out.
 
 Tell me that is not barbaric. Tell me that is not murder.

What is? Whether abortion is right or wrong is a matter of opinion, unless you're trying to say that everyone who supports it secretly is against it. 

 
 Well then. Murder is an opinion.
Murder is a legal term which does not apply to abortion in the United States.

Murder is a legal term which does not apply to abortion in the United States.

 
 Murder is also a moral term and does apply.

Yeah, it's great.
 But, Abortion avocates said that they would challenge the law in the Courts.

 The recently passed partial birth abortion law is going to come before the Supreme Court more sooner than later. People believe that if it comes before a Court that contains a greater number of liberal minded Justices the law will be abolished as un-Constitutional. I agree with this only if the lawyers use the same approach they have used since Roe vs. Wade.
 In reviewing this monumental case, we discover that on several occasions the Justices asked for scientific proof that the fetus is alive. This proof was never given.
 Is a fetus alive? When does a human become a human? These are two questions that are often answered differently by liberals and conservatives. Many people, including scientists, often take a philosophical approach to answering these questions. Since philosophy is only speculation, it does not belong in a courtroom. This creates the biggest problem the new law will have in standing up to the Supreme Court: the pages of explanation that accompany it are based on a common morality and not on hard science.
 I ask again, is a fetus alive? To answer this scientifically, we must ask another question; what is the basic scientific definition of being alive? A living organism according to science carries out metabolism, grows and reproduces. As soon as a sperm and egg are united, the zygote fits the definition of being alive.
 With partial birth abortions, the fact that the fetus is alive is even more evident. If it is not alive, why does the doctor have to perform an action to kill it before it is completely born?
 Often we also run into a second question; when does a human become a human? Numerous books could be quoted that give debates about this and the age-old question as to what makes a human a human. Once again, let us look at it solely from a scientific point of view. When a crime is committed and a bloodstain is found, how do scientists determine whether or not it belongs to and animal or a human? They perform a DNA test. DNA, not consciousness, should be the determinant for the fetus also. Once again, as soon as the sperm and egg untie, they contain a full human genome. Although the National Enquirer and other magazines like it may argue, humans can only create humans. This is another scientific fact.
 I believe that if the lawyers present this information to the Supreme Court, regardless of the liberal/ conservative make-up of the Justices, they would be forced to accept that a fetus is a living human and, as such, protected by the Constitution. However, if the philosophical debate is continued, the Justices will be forced to fall back on their own personal philosophical beliefs.

A living organism according to science carries out metabolism, grows and reproduces. As soon as a sperm and egg are united, the zygote fits the definition of being alive.
 
 
 You almost got it right. A living organism is has the potential of reproduction (unless biologically and abnormally impaired and unable to reproduce by this impairment). By your definition, we really would not be alive until we reproduce. So what, around puberty, 12 or 13 y/o? 
 
 
Often we also run into a second question; when does a human become a human? Numerous books could be quoted that give debates about this and the age-old question as to what makes a human a human. Once again, let us look at it solely from a scientific point of view. When a crime is committed and a bloodstain is found, how do scientists determine whether or not it belongs to and animal or a human? They perform a DNA test. DNA, not consciousness, should be the determinant for the fetus also. Once again, as soon as the sperm and egg untie, they contain a full human genome. Although the National Enquirer and other magazines like it may argue, humans can only create humans. This is another scientific fact.
 
 
 There are many qualifiers to being human, solely containing the DNA does not exactly make it in my book. A zygote may contain the full human genome, but this does not make it a person. If it did, why wouldn't we name our zygotes? Why don't we celebrate our conception day rather than our birthday? Why don't we have a funeral when a woman has a miscarriage early in pregnancy? Why don't you ever see a tombstone in the graveyard saying aged -7 months? These may sound silly to you, but I think they suggest an overall attitude by our society that the moment of birth is the moment we become humans in this world.

You almost got it right. A living organism is has the potential of reproduction (unless biologically and abnormally impaired and unable to reproduce by this impairment). By your definition, we really would not be alive until we reproduce. So what, around puberty, 12 or 13 y/o? 

 
 Reproduction and Growth have the same definition; reproduction of cells (growth). Some people arn't even able to every reproduce at all, genetically. However, yes, you're partially correct, it has to do with the potential of reproduction. So what? 
 
 
There are many qualifiers to being human, solely containing the DNA does not exactly make it in my book. A zygote may contain the full human genome, but this does not make it a person. If it did, why wouldn't we name our zygotes? Why don't we celebrate our conception day rather than our birthday? Why don't we have a funeral when a woman has a miscarriage early in pregnancy? Why don't you ever see a tombstone in the graveyard saying aged -7 months? These may sound silly to you, but I think they suggest an overall attitude by our society that the moment of birth is the moment we become humans in this world.

 
 That's irrelivent. Quite honestly, we usually don't know the conception day, and if we did I would never feel comfortable telling people "I had sex with my wife on this day of her fertility! Happy Conception Day, son!" However, many cultures do celebrate the Conception instead of birth, including the Chinese.
 
 Are you saying that "Life begins because of his birthday says so"?

Are you saying that "Life begins because of his birthday says so"?
 
 
 Did I say that? I don't think so. I said: 
I think they suggest an overall attitude by our society that the moment of birth is the moment we become humans in this world.
 
 
 Why does it not surprise me that you of all people don't understand?

[QUOTE=sundowner]You almost got it right. A living organism is has the potential of reproduction (unless biologically and abnormally impaired and unable to reproduce by this impairment). By your definition, we really would not be alive until we reproduce. So what, around puberty, 12 or 13 y/o? 
 
 It does reproduce. Its cells divide shortly after conception. This is classified as reproduction. All the cells in the human body reproduce themselves until we die. This is what it means to reproduce, not just to create another replica of ourselves. By your understanding not only would we not be alive until we were 9 years old, women would also cease to be alive after menopause. 
 
 <There are many qualifiers to being human, solely containing the DNA does not exactly make it in my book. A zygote may contain the full human genome, but this does not make it a person. If it did, why wouldn't we name our zygotes? 
 
 Some of us do name our zygotes :-) Others just are not prepared I guess.
 The reason an official name is not given until the child is born is that carrying a child to term without having it die is more difficult than people realize. Children also do not have to be named at the time of birth, and in some countries are even given temporary names. Also, consider that we name pets and scientists and farmers give names and numbers to other animals. Does this mean that these animals are also human upon receiving their names?
 
 <Why don't we celebrate our conception day rather than our birthday? 
 
 In some countries, everybody’s birthday is celebrated on the same day at the end of the year. Does that mean that a person born in February in that country is not alive until then?
 
 <Why don't we have a funeral when a woman has a miscarriage early in pregnancy? 
 
 Some women do have a funeral to help them get over it. Others prefer to just try to forget. (I am not saying that it is ever truly possible to forget, but everyone deals with grief differently.)
 
 <Why don't you ever see a tombstone in the graveyard saying aged -7 months? 
 
 Even if a child is born prematurely, as soon as his head "crowns" is the time we begin counting his life. (Even for stillborn children.) Therefore, when you are walking in a graveyard or you look through the obituaries and you see b. Jan 7, 2000, d. Jan. 7, 2000 it is possible (an very probable) that some of these children were premature.

It does reproduce. Its cells divide shortly after conception. This is classified as reproduction. All the cells in the human body reproduce themselves until we die. This is what it means to reproduce, not just create another replica of ourselves. By your understanding not only would we not be alive until we were 9 years old, women would also cease to be alive after menopause
 
 
 
 Cellular REPLICATION is not the same as sexual reproduction. By reproduction, it is understood in this context as sperm + egg = zygote. By saying something has the potential to reproduce, you are saying it can provide one of the addants for this equation. 
 
 And as far as the rest of your post, again:
 
 
I think they suggest an overall attitude by our society  that the moment of birth is the moment we become humans in this world.
 
 
 Don't read too much into it, it is as simple as it sounds there sparky.

[QUOTE=sundowner]Cellular REPLICATION is not the same as sexual reproduction. By reproduction, it is understood in this context as sperm + egg = zygote. By saying something has the potential to reproduce, you are saying it can provide one of the addants for this equation. 
 
 Once again, if this definition were the true scientific meaning defining life, living organisms that reproduce solely by asexual reproduction would not be considered alive. Plants like the century plant, which reproduce once every 100 years, would only be considered alive during their reproductive cycle.
 Our cells reproduce identical copies of themselves. Algae and bacteria cells reproduce identical copies of themselves. Sexual reproduction is not a qualifier for being a living organism. 
 I agree that an organism must be able to produce offspring. However, the organism has to only do this once during its entire lifetime to be considered alive. A zygote has this potential. Science does not limit life to an organism’s reproductive cycle.

Why does it not surprise me that you of all people don't understand?

 
 You seem to be the only one making misstatements.

Cellular REPLICATION is not the same as sexual reproduction. By reproduction, it is understood in this context as sperm + egg = zygote. By saying something has the potential to reproduce, you are saying it can provide one of the addants for this equation. 
 
 Once again, if this definition were the true scientific meaning defining life, living organisms that reproduce solely by asexual reproduction would not be considered alive. Plants like the century plant, which reproduce once every 100 years, would only be considered alive during their reproductive cycle.
 Our cells reproduce identical copies of themselves. Algae and bacteria cells reproduce identical copies of themselves.

 
 First off, we are talking about humans, not plants, I never mentioned asexual reproduction. Second, I use the term POTENTIAL. I have not made the statement that a fetus is not alive. I have not made the statement that a zygote was not alive. 
 
 
Sexual reproduction is not a qualifier for being a living organism. 
 
 
 For humans (I somehow thought that is what we were talking about, not botany) the potential to sexually reproduce is a qualifier. Our species is self renewing through sexual reproduction. For all living things you may use the blanket term reproduction, for humans it become specific to sexual reproduction.
 
 
I agree that an organism must be able to produce offspring. However, the organism has to only do this once during its entire lifetime to be considered alive. A zygote has this potential. Science does not limit life to an organism's reproductive cycle.

 
 
 Wrong again, the organism does not have to reproduce at all to be considered alive. It must have the potential to perpetuate the species (again: unless biologically and abnormally impaired and unable to reproduce by this impairment). 
 
 
You seem to be the only one making misstatements.
 
 
 Pardon?

[QUOTE=sundowner] 1. I have not made the statement that a fetus is not alive. I have not made the statement that a zygote was not alive. 
 2. For humans (I somehow thought that is what we were talking about, not botany) the potential to sexually reproduce is a qualifier. 
 3. Wrong again, the organism does not have to reproduce at all to be considered alive. It must have the potential to perpetuate the species (again: unless biologically and abnormally impaired and unable to reproduce by this impairment). 
 
 1. We are talking about biology which encompasses all life. Scientifically, an organism is considered alive (no matter which kingdom it resides in all the qualifiers are the same) if it meets certain criteria. Look in any high school textbook or above and you will see that these criteria for life are met by a zygote. 
 2.Dealing with whether or not it is a human is a separate factor. For this I give the DNA as a qualifier. sexuall reproduction does not qualify us as human. 
 3. Yes, an organism has to reproduce to be considered alive. Research your facts before posting them. reproduction can be in anyform - viruses are considered to reproduce even though they use a hosts cells mechanisms to do it. (They are not considered to be alive though since they can not carry out metabolism). When you consider the ability to reporduce you do not have to add the qualifier :unless biologically and abnormally impaired and unable to reproduce by this impairment. This is a given it is about whther the organisms on a whole can reproduce not whether or not certain members of the population can do it.
 
 Perhaps you do not understand what I am saying. You are trying to relate social factors and not scientific fact for your belief that a child is not a child until he or she is born. I have not met a woman yet who wanted their unborn child and did not begin caressing it (by rubbing their stomachs), talking with the child, and playing music for him/her from the moment they realized they were carrying one. In my own case, my husband and I even begin playing games with our children as early as the fourth month. We do not start earlier because the womb is not sensitive for a woman to feel the child’s response.
